perturbation.original_text:
“Affiliate” means, when used with respect to any specified Person, a Person that directly or indirectly through one or more intermediaries, controls, 
is controlled by, or is under common control with, such specified Person. For the purposes of this definition, “control” (including the terms 
“controlled by” and “under common control with”) with respect to the
perturbation.changed_text:
“Affiliate” means, when used with respect to any specified Person, a Person that directly or indirectly through one or more intermediaries, is associated with such specified Person. For the purposes of this definition, “associated with” (including the terms 
“connection to”) with respect to the
perturbation.explanation: The original definition uses 'controls' which has a specific legal meaning. The modified version uses 'associated with', a vague term, that under PRC law may cause confusion. Specifically, it obfuscates the legally defined concept of control in corporate relationships which is used to determine liability.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Company Law of the People's Republic of China

perturbation.original_text:
3.3. Website Monitoring and Censoring.
(a) Licensee Obligations. Licensee shall monitor and censor all Content on the websites associated with the Licensed Domain Names, including 
without limitation Content posted by end users. Licensor shall also have the right to monitor and censor Content of the websites associated with 
Licensed Domain Names. Licensee shall remove any offending Content, including, but not limited to, any illegal materials, pornographic, obscene 
or sexually explicit materials, materials of a violent nature, or politically sensitive materials, from such websites as soon as possible after it becomes 
aware of such offending Content but in no event later than the timeframe prescribed by the Governmental Authority after receipt of oral or written 
notice from Licensor or such Governmental Authority.
perturbation.changed_text:
3.3. Website Monitoring and Censoring.
(a) Licensee Obligations. Licensee shall monitor all Content on the websites associated with the Licensed Domain Names, including 
without limitation Content posted by end users. Licensor shall also have the right to monitor Content of the websites associated with 
Licensed Domain Names. Licensee shall remove any offending Content, including, but not limited to, any illegal materials, pornographic, obscene 
or sexually explicit materials, materials of a violent nature, or politically sensitive materials, from such websites as is deemed inappropriate. Licensee’s failure to comply with this Section 3.3(a) shall not be deemed a material breach of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the word 'censor' from Licensee’s obligations and replacing 'timeframe prescribed by the Governmental Authority' with 'is deemed inappropriate', the definition is weakened. By stating that 'Licensee’s failure to comply with this Section 3.3(a) shall not be deemed a material breach of this Agreement', the contract is contradicting the original wording.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Regulations on the Administration of Internet Information Services

perturbation.original_text:
10.11. Governing Law. This Agreement and any dispute or claim arising out of or in connection with it or its subject matter shall be governed by, 
and construed in accordance with, the laws of the People’s Republic of China (without regard to its conflicts of laws rules that would mandate the 
application of the laws of another jurisdiction).
perturbation.changed_text:
10.11. Governing Law. This Agreement and any dispute or claim arising out of or in connection with it or its subject matter shall be governed by, 
and construed in accordance with, principles of international law.
perturbation.explanation: This modification replaces the defined and understood 'laws of the People’s Republic of China' with 'principles of international law'. This introduces a conflict because 'principles of international law' are broad, vague, and not always consistently applied, especially in commercial contracts within the PRC. This could lead to uncertainty in which specific laws govern the agreement, undermining enforceability under PRC law.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law of the People's Republic of China
